text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Finland's security police Supo illegally tapped telephones at least in the 1960s and 1970s, former Supo detective reveals.

- Many registered as unemployed are incapable of working, making the unemployment rate higher than reality, says Esa Harmala, chairman of the Confederation of Industry and Employers (TT) and CEO of forest industry group Enso Oy.
- Uusimaa tax authority has examined staff personal computers to find an information leak; three inspectors have filed charges against the office for the intrusion of privacy.
- Municipalities use varying principles in charging value-added-tax for services; the boundaries of VAT laws are determined in courts.
- All 50,000 tickets for Irish rockband U2's concert in Helsinki in August were sold out in one day on Monday.

- Kesko's plans to sell most of Tuko may run into a timing problem since its letter of intent with the buyers expires on April 30 while an EU source said the Commission does not plan a decision until the May 18 official start of summmer.
- Competition authority may demand that credit card commission be paid by consumers to improve transparency, official says.
KAUPPALEHTI
- European court ruling forcing Finland to change taxation on corporate cars will return about one billion markka to companies.
- Planned EU agreement on carbon dioxide emission cuts would put Finland into a very difficult situation unless more nuclear power is built, ministry of trade and industry report says.
AAMULEHTI

- Group of professors working on Finnish report about the effects of European economic and monetary union (EMU) are due to give an interim statement on April 1 and the final report is due on May 6, sources say.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Northern European security would weaken dramatically if Finland abandoned its non-alliance policy, says MEP and former social democratic party chairman Pertti Paasio.
DEMARI
- Finnish businesses should refocus export efforts to South America from the more competitive Asian markets, says Finland's commercial attache in Chile Kenneth Jofs.
HUFVUDSTADSBLADET
- New cuts threaten farming as government meets on Tuesday to decide on the framework for the state budgets for 1998-2001.
